paragraphs.text: Philippines-China standoff: David vs Goliath?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: In recent years, the South China Sea has (once again) transformed into a theatre of competition among rival claimant states
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Outmatched and outgunned by China, the Philippines has sought to resolve the disputes by resorting to legal arbitration, hoping that international law, particularly the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), will serve as an amicable basis for settling maritime conflicts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But China has unequivocally rejected the arbitration process as an infringement on its national sovereignty and territorial integrity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: recently releasing a position paper that details its rationale for opposing any third- party intervention in the disputes

paragraphs.text: The South China Sea represents a potential flashpoint with global ramifications
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Connecting one of the most dynamic economies of the 21st century, the waters facilitate more than $5 trillion in annual trade
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Crucially, the bulk of the energy imports of industrial powerhouses such as Japan and South Korea pass through the South China Sea
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The very economic survival and energy security of major Asian economies is anchored by unimpeded access to international waters such as the South China Sea
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Almost everyone has an interest in the peaceful settlement of the disputes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But it is far from certain whether the Philippines' legal manoeuvre will contribute to the de-escalation of maritime tensions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: China has vehemently rejected the entire arbitration process, accusing the Philippines of stirring trouble and jeopardising historically stable bilateral ties
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Technically, the maritime disputes involve six rival claimant states: China, Brunei, Malaysia, the Philippines, Vietnam, and Taiwan
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The bitterest disputes, however, involve China, on one hand, and the Philippines and Vietnam, on the other

paragraphs.text: In the absence of any tangible compliance-enforcement mechanism, China can reject any unfavourable judicial outcome; launch a media campaign to delegitimise the arbitration proceedings; contemplate sanctions and other forms of diplomatic counter-manoeuvres to isolate the Philippines; and project toughness (to its domestic hyper-nationalist audience) by stepping up its activities in the area
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Ultimately, the best solution may lie in direct engagement, confidence- building measures, and sustained bilateral negotiations rather than compulsory arbitration
